content: The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" establishes awards for schools under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to promote innovation in technology. The purpose of this part is to expand knowledge about advanced technology in education, address national questions, and develop innovative teaching models for widespread adoption. The Secretary is authorized to award grants for these initiatives. The Secretary is authorized to award grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements on a competitive basis through the Office of Educational Technology to eligible applicants for a period of up to 5 years. "Eligibility for grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements through the Office of Educational Technology is authorized for up to 5 years." To be eligible for an award under this program, applicants must form a consortium including a State or local educational agency and an institution with relevant expertise. The application must include a project description and a plan for independent evaluation with progress benchmarks. The Secretary may establish priorities for awarding grants under this program. The Secretary may establish priorities for awarding grants under this program, including innovative models for educational technology, projects serving multiple states, innovative models for underserved populations, and projects with substantial resources. Priority for projects under this program include serving low-income students, students with disabilities, and those with limited English proficiency. Additionally, priorities are given to projects with substantial financial resources, innovative models for using electronic networks, and establishing high-speed internet access. Priority for projects under this program include serving low-income students, students with disabilities, and those with limited English proficiency. Additionally, priorities are given to projects with substantial financial resources, innovative models for using electronic networks, and establishing high-speed internet access. Uses of funds are outlined in SEC. 3213. The recipient of funds awarded under this program must use them to develop new educational technologies, integrate technology across the curriculum, and carry out activities like improving teachers' ability to integrate technology and developing high-quality digital content. The recipient of funds must develop high-quality digital content, including multimedia software, digital video, web-based resources, new technological formats for better subject understanding, computer modeling tools, student performance assessment methods, distance learning curricula, and learning-focused digital libraries. The use of technology in education includes creating interoperable software components, digital libraries for reusing learning content, and software for developing educational materials. Additionally, technology is used to make programs accessible to students with special needs and provide opportunities for female students to explore technology careers. The curr_chunk discusses promoting school-family partnerships, providing opportunities for female students to explore technology careers, acquiring necessary resources for projects, and collaborating with other technology research programs. The Secretary is authorized to develop tools, provide resources, offer technical assistance, conduct evaluations, and disseminate findings for activities funded under this part. Recipients of funds are limited to using 3 percent for administrative costs. A non-federal share is required for funds received under this part. SEC. 3215 limits administrative costs to 3% of funds awarded. SEC. 3216 requires recipients to share costs, not exceeding 50%. SEC. 3217 authorizes appropriations. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2001 and beyond. Repeal of former program for National Challenge Grants with conforming amendments. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2001 and beyond are revised by making amendments to specific sections, including renumbering and restructuring certain provisions.
